text: I feel very sad for the people. It's terrible. Not only the people but the animals as well! Yeah, the whole situation is horrible. I really wish there was something i could do.

I know we can donate, but it's hard to know exactly how the money is used. I agree. Have you ever been in a hurricane? No, and You? Yes! It's actually terrifying. We were supposed to evacuate but decided to stay because we thought , what's the worst that can happen?

Yeah, it's going to be tough but i am sure she is strong enough to raise them.

Yeah, we never know what we can do unless we are tested. True. Have you been in ANY kind of natural disasters? Tornado when I was young. They suck too. Never been in one but i can only imagine it's even scarier than a hurricane

The power of nature is truly scary. Agree. I hope those people get some water and food as soon as possible Me too, I wish there was a direct way to aid the people. Yup! Well it was nice talking to you! bye You too! bye

makes sense. also find better ways rather than trucks that are easily looted by the people ahh so true!also insure that when you say there is enough for everyone that there actually is. and also not let the haitian govt get there hands on any of it they are corrupt America should dethrone the government and make it the 51st state

Please, what did you think about the article It's very sad.   I can't believe in the 21st century that people are still so slow in helping third world countries or even in the US when New Orleans was destroyed.   It makes no sense. It's terrible. I feel bad for all the people left without shelter! And food - you can get by in Haiti without much shelter but one must have clean water and food to live

Agree. Have you ever been in a hurricane? I have not but I have been to Haiti on a mission trip.   Such wonderful kind people. Wow, Haiti sounds awesome. I'm from Florida so there's lots of them here and they are all nice. That would be so much stress.   I live in Colorado so just beautiful white snow.

It's pretty stressful when hurricanes hit. I once stayed for one even though we were supposed to evacuate, nobody was hurt but it was a scary experience I have been near tornadoes and they look bad enough.  I can't imagine a hurricane. It's scary because all you can do is hide in your home hoping it passes by without doing much damage. I hope the people affected by the hurricane are getting help right now. I follow college basketball like a crazy person.   Skal Labiesse was trapped in the hurricane in this article.   His whole home collapsed on him and he was covered with rock and materials for three days.   His story is so frightening.   He thought he was dying

Yeah it's definitely very different. The air pressure feels different when you're in a hurricane. All you hear are sounds of things ripping apart ourside Wow.   Are you on the gulf or the Atlantic? Atlantic, i've lived in Florida for about 8 years now and luckyily haven't had any MAJOR hurricane yet. That's good to hear.   Haiti has such a corrupt government - I wonder how much their President stole from the people so he had fun for a long time. I didn't think of that. That's why i don't even donate but i feel bad because i can't help It's gotten to that point everywhere unless a church is doing all the work.   American Cancer Society, March of Dimes, United Way - hardly any goes to the people or cause you are donating to - it's all taken in outlandish salaries of that charity Sad that people are so corrupt. I really hope those people get help. It was nice talking to you! bye! You too goodbye
what a sad thing to happen to someone who has gone through so much and at such a young age too. what a freak accident yeah, they didn't really elaborate on what happened though

he had the true american dream story more or less, most people can't throw 94 mph fast balls though. yup but going from poor to crazy rich all from hard work. love to see it seemed to be a pretty altruistic guy too. There wasn't anything but goodwill toward him.

I wonder if the team retired his number to honor him hm, i wouldn't know. Do you follow baseball? yes, I watch the yankees almost every night. How about you? I like to play baseball, but watching it never really thrills me. Are the Yankees in the playoffs this year?

yes! they made it to the playoffs! that's great! Had you heard about this guy before reading the article? Seems like he was kind of a big deal. I heard about it in the news when it happened but I don't follow baseball to close just the yankees. I bet he was a pretty big deal on his team. do you think it was just a freak accident? Or, was there more to the boat wreck than was indicated?

I remember hearing he jumped into the water head first into a rock and it killed him instantly. huh, the article made it sound like it was a wreck at high speed or something. The rock story seems less conspicuous. i couldn't imagine being the family of him that had to be horrible no doubt. well thanks for chatting with me. Go Yankees! bye bye

Sounded like a very kindhearted man. Yes so sad that his life ended this way I was wondering if no drugs or alcohol were involved what happened? Maybe an inexperienced person trying to drive the boat?

That could have been it. Boating can be quite dangerous if you dont know what you are doing It was nice that he saved his mom not knowing it was her. Yes very nice.  It sounds like they had a hard life in cuba

Yeah, It was nice for the team to get the visa. Im sure his life was quite different after beginning his baseball career yeah, so sad that it was cut so short. very sad. from the reading material he sounded like a great person

yeah and did not change much when he got his baseball money. yes it sounds like he stayed true to himself He must had a lot of trust for the driver of the boat. I dont know how the driver managed to hit the rocks at full speed. Youd have to see something like that coming
That what I was thinking. It is not a pretty way to die. No not at all. A real tragedy for sure He was a very good player too. One of the best. It was nice chatting! bye You too, goodbye

Sad about what happened to those guys.  I hope no one makes this about alcohol or anything. Yes after all the struggle to get to where he was Right. I can't imagine being his family either.  To see their child go like that after being so successful has to sting. absolutely growing up in Cuba and then achieving so much

I don't remember if it said so in the article or not, but was it night when they ran into the rocks? I just don't get why they didn't see them? I remember when this happened saw it on ESPN but I think it was night At least it was probably instant.  They probably had no idea the rocks were there and absolutely flew into them without any chance to realize what was going on. yea it would suck to be in a coma

Lol I think it would suck more to come out of a coma.  When you're in it you have no idea.  I would hate coming out of one and realizing you lost a month of your life or something. I wonder what you think about in a coma I feel like there's lots of stories out there about people saying they saw everything but from the third person perspective or things like that. Other people say it was just the deepest sleep they've ever had. the mind is a trip

For real.  Obviously they don't know everything about it, but it blows my mind when I watch docs or something where people are breaking down the parts of the brain... Like, how the fuck did we figure all this stuff out... yea I love watching that stuff I'm the only one who's not a doctor in my family but I'm still in the medical field we used to have some real interesting dinner convos What do you do in the medical field? Surgical Technologist

Damn.  Sounds cool.  Do you just sit in on surgeries and assist? Yea my job is to get all the instruments ready and basically be an extra pair of hands for the surgeon handing him all the instruments and helping him with the surgery. A good surgical tech knows the surgery just as well as the surgeon so he/she never has to ask for anything you should anticipate it Yeah I here ya, probably makes the operation flow a lot smoother when the surgeon asks for a tool and you're not fumblefuckin around looking to find the blahblahmeter. yea they get super pissed if you waste time each minute counts

what's the longest surgery you;ve ever taken part in? 8 hour spinal surgery Yikes.  Well if Jose would've survived he probaby would have needed at least an 8 hour spinal surgery. yes for sure it was nice talking to you goodbye bye.
Hello what did you think about the articlee? I thought it shows how people can really change Definitely. I felt so bad for the children at first. yes they get caught up in the system

They should be in school and making friends! I know well who knows how safe school is now a days I had a cousin who went to jail at a young age, he never really changed. some people get caught up in that life i have friends that will always be in jail

I definitely believe that people can't really change. what about you? I think most people can but some are real sociopaths Maybe my cousin is just a sociopath. I hope those kids that got out find good jobs in the future. yea its hard because people are scared to hire people who were in the system even if they change

I think that if i owned a business, i would definitely think twice about a person who served time yea me too How would you feel about someone in your family marrying a person that went to jail before? it would depend on the crime I guess What if it's minor like stealing, but has done it many times. I don't know about multiple offenses maybe if it was a max of 2 times Very interesting! Well it was nice talking to you! bye you too bye

What did you think of this? this was so sad i never really thought of kids in foster care and how hard it was It is sad for them, no child should have to endure all that agreed and not there fault they had behavioral issues

well, yes and no.  we all have personal responsibility for our choices in my opinion.  regardless of circumstance They needed more direction and structure they didnt get in the system yes they definitely did, it failed them it is nice he changed his life around and is helping others now

yes that was the best part of the article Yeah I did not expect that honestly yeah, to turn something good from something bad and now hes helping others Agreed, I hope eventually the system is fixed and structured better

yes it needs help, but i think there is a lack of good foster parents yeah i know alot just do it for tax and write offs and are horrible caretakers to the kids yeah exactly!!!  And then the kids are mistreated, so saf I dont know how they do it so resiliant Yeah the human soul has remarkable resilience true it is amazing to read about Yes, and this was a pretty amazing, sad story with a good ending.  well I must go, have a good day.  goodbye great goodbye!

What a story! yeah, lots of ups and downs in that one It sounds like the system failed him at an early age unfortunately, i think stories like this are all too common with children who go through the foster system.

For sure. Many fall  through the cracks and its so sad. it's really crazy that those two brothers ended up in the same prison I know! What are the odds? astronomical. Do you have any thoughts on how the foster system could be improved?

I'd say have more oversight of individual cases. So many children arent getting the attention on their cases that they need. Do you have any suggestions? I agree, I also think that counseling services should be provided by the state Absolutely. And also some sort of self sufficiency classes for those who are about to age out of the system I think we could all benefit from self sufficiency/life skills classes as teenagers.

My school had them every week and I loved it. Learned a lot of life skills What kind of skills did you learn? Sewing, vehicle maintenance, budgeting, childcare, basic home repairs, tax basics, etc. interesting, I don't think my high school offered classes like that. We had home economics, but that was primarily cooking and cleaning.

I think all schools should offer classes like that. Theyre very beneficial Agreed. What did you think of the sibling that eventually got his masters and now helps kids in similar situations? I think its amazing how he turned his life around. A true inspiration It's crazy how differently people react to similar circumstances. Thanks for chatting with me today. bye Great talking to you. Goodbye

Hello. The situation in India is really terrible Tell me about it. What a shame that the government of India isn't taking action. It's all about profit to them it seems. Apparently. The most worrisome part of the situation is the fact that they barely compensate the victims It's such a shame and a human rights abuse. Every living creature for that matter has a basic right to clean air and water. I couldn't imagine how bad it must be living near one of those mines.

Indeed. What do you think can be done on the part of the citizens in order to draw attention of the international communities? Any change with government happens when people join together en mass. They need to be protesting outside of every politicians office. They should also spread this story to the international community to publicly shame their officials. Do you have any ideas of what can be done? In all honesty, I have no idea. I can think of how in the US change was created with the civil rights movement, and the women's movement when people stood together. I think that because people like us know about the story we can help by sharing this information on social media. We can be the media for them. But what can be done about the poor elephants? They have lost their homes because of the forest's being destroyed.

It's left for their government to decide Ultimately yes. So it's up to everyone to make sure their government works in their best interest. Some people not even receiving compensation was terrible, but what about the kids who lost their lives? No amount of money can replace life. True. It's really pathetic There should be some sort of a program that helps these elephants get transported to a place where their homes won't be destroyed. Do you know of any charities that could help?

Nope. I doubt if the government will allow that. You really don't think they would allow international help? I will pose the question... What would you do if this were happening in your hometown? The government in India is corrupt. They are involved in the illegal trade of ivory. They won't allow any external body to interfere with their business You make a really good point. I wasn't thinking about that.

I've read series of disturbing stories about their activities in the illegal trade of ivory I've actually heard about that a while ago. Like I stated earlier... They care about profits over people. Yeah. It's all about the rupees I'm afraid that they will hurt these communities to the point where they create a refugee crisis.

That's the reality. At the very least I wonder if we could donate things like breathing masks? Maybe that could help some to breath a bit better. Or if there is a way to get them clean water delivered. That won't be a bad idea. How do "we" go about that I would imagine that we could set up a GoFundMe campaign. That's definitely one way to go about it.

There have been several scam cases with GFM There are alternative platforms. I would be happy to research them in detail. Charities can be looked into as well. That'll be great It's the least we can do, and like I said, posting on social media would help raise awareness. I just wish we could wave a wand and these communities would have clean air and water. goodbye bye

The effect is terrible it is only one of many issues affecting the poorer population, but yea I think humans are generally selfish the article read mostly of financial and political greed. they just don't care

Yea, It is sad and pathetic. can't even blame the elephants if everything is getting destroyed. agricultural expansion is one and thing, but coal mining adds a lot more of dangerous stuff to the environment Yea, the pollution is massive. i wonder how far the situation will have to deteriorate for them to be like Oh wait, maybe this wasn't such a good idea.

I dont see that happening sincerely. The are rich, they can afford moving to another planet! what annoys me too is that the people receive promises after the fact of like an elephant incursion, but it is just that, empty promises That is what they do. They give false hopes the effort to change at the population level needs to be massive

People should be more orientated. there is still some hope. i recall reading a different article, also from India, dealing with a big volunteer effort toward reforestation Oh, that is great. Reforestation is a great way...I hope people follow it through it was. it took them 15 years, but the new forest is thriving. the issue is the population need to be more conscientious and understand that the benefits might not be seen overnight.

Yea, that is some nice method. i'm kind of running out of things to say, and we need at least 15 messages each that are relevant to the articles yes...I think finding alternatives to coal is also a great idea wind and solar are the first that come to mind

And nuclear sources.. are they capable to handle the necessary infrastructure for that? nobody wants a Chernobyl or Fukushima It is good I think. they need better overall infrastructure. reaching a lot of these places is hard, if not impossible during some parts of the year Yes. can we exchange our byes? we are short a few still good. I have few minutes left here. bye bye

What did you think? I can not blame them for wanting to industrialize, but it still horrible. Yeah. I wish we had better options than coal. It seems like it's wrecking environments everywhere these days. Yeah, the people and animals over there are suffering.

For sure. I can't imagine having an elephant burst through my house! That would be very scary, then told you will get about 120 dollars for your broken leg. Probably wouldn't even pay for a single night's stay in a hospital. It sucks that the people who don't even work in the mines are getting such bad lung diseases.

Yeah. It's bad enough when things like this affect people actually involved, but when you have people getting hurt that weren't even part of it it's just so much worse. I wonder if the animals are having lung issues too? I wouldn't be surprised; many animals have similar lung structures as humans do. It's probably why the elephants etc. have been in so many altercations lately. Like I said, can't get too mad because American used a lot of coal in the 1800s and early to mid 1900s.

Oh for sure. Many of the appalachian areas, for example, still have serious environmental damages and generational health issues. Many of the same areas want to continue mining coals. It sucks that we live in a world where economics out weight health. Yeah. Economics & tradition -- many families have been in the business for so long they can't imagine doing anything else. It's their way of life almost more than it is a living. I know working in the US mine is a lot safer than the mine in India.

True true. Do you think we should be investing in finding cleaner forms of energy? Yes 100 percent. We're in agreement then. Something needs to be done soon before we run out of options & time. I agree, but a lot people can not think about the future or other people besides themselves

"The tyranny of the immediate," as one of my professors once said. I would like my children's children to be able to have a good life. Same. Do you have any further thoughts? No. Very nice chatting with you! bye bye!

So I thought this was a really tragic and avoidable incident, what did you think I was not really bothered, suicides are common common?  I guess.  I don't really see it as an everyday occurence but anyhow No not everyday but people do it and that is their choice

Yep, it is definitely their choice.  I still find it sad and very avoidable.  How sad for all their remaining family members. I see what you mean but don't you think that being sad is just a waste of time? Of course being sad is a waste of time, but it is still appropriate to feel sadness when you hear of a tragedy.  It's not like I'm dressed in black lighting candles and mourning, Jesus Christ. Easy now. I did not mean it as a personal attack. It just doesn't make sense to me to be sad for someone who makes a conscious choice to end their own life. It's their choice

Well then be neutral towards it or happy, that's your right.  I find it sad anytime I hear about a tragedy that happens to others.  I am sad for their family who lost a beloved family member. Let me be clear, I would rather no one commit suicide. How do we know that they were beloved? They could have despised each other Sure they could have, but surely there was at least one person who appreciated this woman.  The article stated as much. A fair point. When you think about it suicide is the easy way out. It is a bit cowardly. Choosing to continue living requires real courage

I agree suicide is extremely cowardly and suicide angers me.  It is a terrible choice for people to make and very selfish bc they are not considering how their actions affect others who are left behind. We can agree on that. Do you know anyone personally who committed suicide? Yes, and dealing with the fallout from it and the years and years of aftermath from that person's loved ones was terrible and very straining on everyone around.  The loved ones are STILL not healed and it has been 13 years I got that impression from your responses. Do you think the loved ones deserve treatment or should preventative measures be the answer to suicide?

Can you clarify your question?  I am not sure I fully understand.  Do you mean grief counseling, or what preventative measures are you referring to?  Like should more have been done to try to help the person to start with? Hospitalization, medication, psychotherapy, or even depriving someone of their freedom temporarily to ensure they do not take their life I think those are reasonable steps to take in some cases but in others it might just make things worse.  I really don't know the answer to that.  If someone is that determined to take their own life it seems they will do it no matter what.  What do you think?  I don't think any of that stuff would have helped int he situation I'm referring to.  But who knows. What do you think causes suicide? Most animals have such a strong will to live. What causes people to abandon or ignore that innate drive?

That's an interesting point about animals.  We don't see them giving up and killing themselves.  Fascinating question, I have no idea what it is about humans.  Maybe it has just become a part of our culture?  Like if the first animal did it then others would follow?  No clues.  What do you think I am not sure myself. Most animals also do not have complex social structures and constructs like humans. I am sure that with those stark differences it would be good place to start the investigation. Yes I wonder if it has ever been formally studied I was wondering that myself. I think the best animals to study would be primates. I know chimpanzees can suffer from depression but I am not sure whether or not they commit suicide

OH yeah, really good point.  That would be very interesting to find out.  I guess it would be possible that they could because they do a lot of things that we do. True, but they also don't do a lot of things we do and I am not sure whether or not suicide is in the Do or Don't category. yeah exactly.  It is probably in the don't category.  I guess I could see them like refusing to eat or drink more than bringing a knife to their wrist. Refusing food and sexual gratification are some of the things chimpanzees do when they are depressed. Similar symptoms in humans. If they were to commit suicide how do you think they would go about doing it? I would think it would be passive, such as just refusing food and drink until they can't survive.  But maybe the urge to survive would override their depression?  Hard to say.  This has been an interesting conversation and I think we are at 15 messages so I will say goodbye for now and hope you have a great day Yes very interesting. I hope you have a good day as well. goodbye bye
I found the article to be sad. Me too, depression is a real issue. It is and it is so difficult for people to seek help. Yeah that is true, I think she wanted help but the system failed her.

Yeah, it did, I feel so bad for her family. It made me think that money and frame does not matter when it comes to depression Considering how many famous people seem to go through that, yeah it doesn't seem to matter. I wonder if being famous adds more pressure and makes a person depressed?

I guess it could, especially if people have to put up a happy face for the public. She should have never been left alone. Yeah, but I think it is difficult to know what to do when someone you love is going through things that you don't understand. That is true, but they knew she was having thoughts of killing herself.

Yeah, but maybe they thought that if they hovered too much, she would feel even worse, I don't know. I guess that is why they have professionals. It is a hard subject. It is something that people don't know much about especially considering how people ignored or locked away people who went through those things in the past. I agree, most people see it was weakness and do not understand what is going on.

Yeah and they tend to shame people who seek help. Or tell them how to deal with it. Yeah, I don't know why that is. People have no problem seeking help when it comes to physical problems like a broken arm, but when it comes to mental problems forget about it. I believe it comes down to people not wanting to be seen as weak. I do not think most people think about depression as chemicals in the brain.

I think that is better than it used to be. Yes, there is a lot more awareness today. Yes, and people are being more understanding about it. Going back to what you said earlier. I feel bad for anybody family that has to go though this.

Yeah, it is has so be so hard for them. It would be the questions about what should you have done. Yeah, and it probably doesn't stop after somebody kills themselves. They probably still go through that their whole lives, what could they have done differently. The internet makes it better and worst.
Oh yeah, so many hateful people who don't care who they hurt. Well, hopeful everybody gets the help they need. I hope so. nice chatting with you. same to you, goodbye bye
Hello How you doing? Good, how are you? Well, Very sad story I must confess

Yeah I have to agree. Stories about suicide are always sad. It was totally avoidable...the woman called for help Yeha. Even more than that she was at the recovery center and they let her go. Depression is real. I mean, she is rich and had it all

Yea it really shows that anybody can be affected by depression. It doesn't mather how much money you have. That is scary... I agree. Do you think the doctors that let her go should face any consequences? Yeah, he should. They took the oath to protect them

I think they should do a thorough investigation with the possibility of revoking the doctors license to practice. Definitely. It will be the best move. Yeah people deserve to be protected from this happening again. Exactly. She left all her wealth behind.
It is just really sad. But what can make rich people fall depressed? I dunno. Maybe she was extremely hard on herself. Yea, she got disconnected from everything...
The way she ended it is also pretty crazy. Its scary..drowning! Jeezzz Yeah just walking into the ocean. I always see suicide as a selfish act though

Yeah it is wierd for me to think about because I do not know what is going through their minds before they do it. I have never even thought about doing it so it is hard to understand. I cant. I will always consider my family and friends Yeah you have to think about how much damage you will do. I always do that Well I think we have done enough turns. Was a good little conversation. yea..bye goodbye

Hello what did you think about the article? It made me very sad.   She had such a hard life.   Whether it's socialized medicine or medicine here in the states, they miss so much with mental illness. I agree. I feel like we are not doing enough about mental illness as a society We aren't.   I am so tired of physicians sending you to a therapist to talk about your childhood or given medicine that doesn't work.   No one listens to the patient at all.

Exactly! It's very rare you find a good therapist. Most of them just can't wait to get home. Yes!   I have suffered from dark depression my entire life.   It has nothing to do with your childhood.   You were wired that way at birth.   To date, physicians are just initially tapping how to help people.    Such a long way to go. It must have been really tough for you. I think i have mild depression and it's such a struggle. Oh it is.   Your family doesn't know how to help.   I just stay exhausted and really never socialize.   It really has nothing for therapists to address.   They can help victims of assault, etc. but they do not help for depression.   At least, that's been the case for me.    I'm sorry you suffer from it.

Yeah it's terrible. I have anxiety as well and everyday is a struggle to be honest Just know I totally understand.   From personal experience, I think anxiety and depression go hand and hand.   I have a lot of anxiety around people or social settings.   What about you? I am the same. I even have trouble going out with close friends sometimes. Just being around people, i don't like.. Yeah me too.   I looked at this article and remember this being in the news.   She did all the "right" things, physicians didn't share nor did they do anything with the statement of suicide.   That's unacceptable.

Yeah i still feel bad for the person in the article. Do you think people in society now are more accepting of mental illnesses? No - they just look at you with that pitiful look and once employers know they look for ways to terminate you - if you had cancer everyone is supportive. That's an interesting way to look at it but i agree. I honestly don't think society will EVER be accepting of people with mental illnesses. They'll always think of us as the "crazy" ones. And your point is exactly why none of us want to convey we have it.   To your point, we are all crazy. Well at least we all know deep down we're great people and just slightly different which makes us special. We are - the thing we have to come to agreement on is how do we not feel like we can't do anything all the time.   I don't ever get a break from those feelings. I get those feelings as well but i think we should tell ourselves that it's okay to have these feelings from time to time. But anyway, that's it for our convo, hope you have a great life and things improve! bye It was nice chatting with you.    goodbye

This article just makes it so clear how little tolerance there really is in the world. It's sad we claim we are all so much more civilized these days, but the truth is we still seem people are more different than the same. It is really sad I find it interesting that so many people still use religion as an excuse for violence and only focus on the most violent parts of the religion and ignore the preachings of tolerance and peace. I was gutted for those that were killed, and nothing was done as well

It is sad that there doesn't seem to be any way to help those people from the article. Even if they wanted to go back so much has been destoryed that you can understand why they'd want to stay away. Thinking about this, I can only think what can really be done to curb this act Until there is a change in the way extremists think and act, I can't see a way this will change. you are absolutely right

I often wonder how a religion that millions can follow peacefully is allowed to be twisted by those same followers and used to do so much evil. Don't you think the islamic followers should do more to police the extremists? I think the Islamic leaders should speak out more against this act I think so too. If religion is such an important aspect of their lives, why don't the leaders have more power to control the out of control elements of their religion? I wonder as too as well

I just don't understand a religion that allows for the harm of those that aren't looking to harm you. I think we should even put religion aside, it is never right to kill another person I agree that killing is wrong. However, regarding this article it is nearly impossible to set religion aside as it is the reason the killings are happening. oh yes you are right. I just wish Christians and Muslims can coexist peacefully

I don't understand why they can't. If both sides have elements of tolerance built right into the religion who is to say it's right to set aside those elements? I think both religion should do all they can to promote peace I wish they would. I mean taking the article into consideration again, even if you forget the killing the damage done in the name of religion needs to be addressed. Both sides need to do more to remember peace, tolerance and acceptance is better than violence and hatred. We can only continue to hope things get better while moving forward

I had never considered the zoo animals in countries like Venezuela. How sad. Me, too. We think about the effects of poverty, war on humans ... but not animals. I was kind of concerned when it started talking about zoo owners being fined or punished. It's not really *their* fault. That's an excellent point. The owners can't change the situation, that isn't fair at all. It isn't as if they want their animals to be sick/die!

I thought that embalming/preserving some of the animals was a valid idea, for science, but only if absolutely necessary and only if they were euthanized humanely. Agreed - I would imagine that would provide a more humane death than starvation/malnutrition. Do you consider yourself to be an animal lover? Definitely. Do you? Absolutely. My grad degree is in Animal Behavior. :)  Do you have any pets?

That's interesting! I do; a dog and a cat. Nice! Do they get along? Yes, thankfully, haha. And the Great Dane that I babysit gets along relatively well, also. That is a lot of dog to babysit! Is your dog a large breed, too?

He's 50-60 lbs, so mid-range? He's a catahoula. I just googled Catahoulas - what gorgeous dogs! And I thought I knew my dog breeds. :) I get a lot of funny looks when i mention his breed, sometimes! He is very handsome. What's his temperament like?

Well, I adopted him at 3.5, so I can't testify what is breed standard and what was due to his previous owner/occupation. He was a military family's dog who "worked" on base, and he accompanied them to work. But he's wonderful. Very calm, emotionally sensitive. Great with kids. Not any of the agression or hyperactivity you hear about the breed. Sounds wonderful - and sounds like you lucked out! Did you adopt him through a special service? No, our local animal shelter, actually. The family was being relocated overseas and the base in the other location didn't allow dogs. They released him to the shelter so that his new home would be checked out and verified safe beforehand. We did luck out! That's even better. I ask because I have friends who adopted a dog that was being trained as a mobility assistant - but he failed the final test after pulling someone out of a wheelchair to chase a rabbit. :)

hahah! those rabbits are tricky! Right? And irresistable! I'm surprised the dog got to the final test, but I guess it's a good thing a rabbit came by LOL, seriously! That would have made for an unpleasant surprise for the new owner

could have been dangerous! but I'm sure he's a lovely pet He was - they taught him to sort recycling (that's Seattle for you) and he was the ring bearer at their wedding precious! It was absurdly sweet

Do you have pets yourself? And did your degree focus on specific species? I do - I'm not sure what happened, but I have cats ... 5 cats. It's a bit terrifying. And, yes, thanks for asking! I'm technically a "primatologist" - I ran around watching monkeys interesting! I almost went into equine studies. instead I got my AKC training certificate and an elementary education degree lol Nice! I work with some folks doing applied animal behavior with dogs. Cool stuff. And I teach at community college, so I'm right there with you! :) I think we've hit our 15, but it was a fun chat with you! Right back at you! Have a lovely day! bye! bye!

I really am not sure how I feel about this article. I think that parents in this situation need to face some type of punishment. Why do you feel that way? Because it is a case of negligence at the core. Because they left a window open and the toddler pushed through the screen? I know that jumping toward negligence is a common emotional reaction to situations like this, but I think that you're misplacing blame in this instance.

Is it not negligent to make sure the window is closed/access blocked? That's like driving down the road with the door open and blaming the kid when they fall out. In my view, a screen should provide enough security to allow the parents to leave the window open, you're analogy doesn't track. Perhaps they were just trying to keep their children's room cool on a balmy summer night. Accidents like this happen all the time. If you're intent on holding someone accountable then their really isn't anyone else to blame, but sometimes things just happen. If you live multiple stories up then you should not leave a window open and if you do access needs to be blocked. Screens are obviously not a deterrent. So yes I think that parents in this situation should be forced to take parenting classes. Most windows are up high enough on a wall that a child could not just walk through them. The child obviously stacked things inside the room to bring himself to window level and then pressed on the screen hard enough (this would take significant force on a properly installed screen) to fall through the window. The child was also four years old, right? At four, most children would have the presence of mind not to engage in such an activity. This is an odd circumstance all things considered. It's terrible to think of a dead child in any context.

Hard to think about this situation for sure. We cannot really assume how high the window was or how intelligent the child is though. This is for the parents to do. Which brings me back to my point, if you know your kid has the ability to engage in such a behavior, take precautions. My little brother burnt our house down when he was 4. My parents always had child proof lighters after that. There are a ton of examples that can be used but it always comes back to the parents. I understand your point, but punishing the parents isn't going to bring the child back. I think that every parent could benefit from education on the basics of child rearing. Right so the "punishment" would be more bringing awareness to the parents. Rather than jail time/cps involvement you make them take parenting classes to prevent this from happening again. I'm pretty sure that they are very aware of the dangers following the events. The real shame is that humanity in general is a very reactive instead of a proactive entity. Tragedies like this are required before any meaningful action is taken across the board.

It is sad for sure. I hope I do not seem too uncaring about this scenario it just triggers anger rather than sympathy as this is something that could have been avoided though I can imagine the parents feel the guilt more than anybody else. anger is a completely natural response to situations like this I was just picturing the parents sitting in the living room confident in the fact that their children were safe while one lay dead in the parking lot below Yea I can imagine that was a tough thing to experience. Sucks that their other little kid will never meet his brother. Yeah, so sympathy was my first response. Do you have children?

I do not have children but do have nieces and nephews. I am able to feel sympathy, anger and be critical at the same time though. Sympathy doesn't change the facts. Well, considering we don't have all the facts I think that's a pretty foolish statement. Fact 1- the window was left open with only a screen. Fact 2- the screen was not secured in place. Fact 3- The parents could not heard from the living room to the kids room. Those seem to be easily understood facts. Your second and third facts are assumptions. The screen could have been secure, but the full weight of a four year old child being pressed against it over an extended period of time could certainly dislodge it. The whole process could have been relatively silent as those details weren't included in the article, hence my statement about having all the facts. It seems your anger is causing you to attempt to establish things as fact that simply can't be substantiated. Thanks for chatting! bye have a good one! bye

So, how did you respond to the article? I think it's so terrible and horribly sad. Just another reminder of the damage we are continuing to do to the environment and the earth. Are you able to empathize with the people who are responsible for the spill and the subsequent clean up? Meaning, can you picture yourself being so concerned with money that you are effectively willing to destroy people's livelihoods? I can understanding needing and wanting money and doing things you don't like to get it. But I can't imagine getting money in such a way that I'd hurt so many other people in the process and ruin an entire river. I can't imagine being that kind of person.

I think there's a sociopathic dehumanization that occurs in people like that. Like, the people potentially affected are seen as so far beneath them that they can't effectively relate to their circumstances. I don't know if they even really think about other people at all. I mean, I feel that someone so focused on their own wealth above all else doesn't even take the time to consider other people in their plans at all. I don't think they even care as long as they are obtaining their goals. I think you are probably correct. I wish it would have specified what kind of mine it was. We can't keep raping the earth for corporate gain. No we can't. I don't think it really even matters what kind of mine it was. There isn't anything in the earth worth damaging an entire river and disrupting so many people's lives.

What would you consider an alternative to these destructive practices? Well altneratives really depend on what type of mine it was. Basically for coal stop using fossils fuels. We have the ability to use wind, solar and water and we need to focus more on that. For minerals and gold and such, we need to figure out new manufacturing processes or start limiting the desire for those types of things so that mining isn't worth it. Considering the fact that diamonds can now be convincingly replicated in laboratories, I can't see why the future might not unveil a sort of alchemical equivalent of changing abundant materials into formerly rare materials. That would be a nice thought. It's going to take some major changes from everyone on earth to make a difference. I hope that we wake up to that and start now. It can't be done overnight and we need to start somewhere.

The pessimist in me often entertains the thought that we have passed a point of no return when it comes to our environment. I believe that a low energy future will be visited upon humanity by force, not by choice. I am afraid that for a lot of things you might be right. I'd hope we could make the change because it's the right thing to do. However, I fear that for a lot of things it's going to come down to we have no other choice. Sad to think, but people don't often change unless forced to. Change is scary. People are afraid of what they don't understand and that is why human society has had no long lasting fundamental shifts in centuries. Our only hope is that our past won't be forgotten once we get a chance to start over. I'd like to hope that we'd learn from our mistakes, but it seems we only learn the lesson for so long and then we backslide. I think it's not even so much fearing the change as the fact that so many people fear for their money and industry that makes money now are things we need to move away from. Do you feel that free market capitalism is a viable ideology moving forward? I think it would be if it was a true free market system. But too often we say it's free market and yet we bail out companies because they are "too big to fail" but in a true free market if you fail you fail. Hey, I really enjoyed our chat! Have a good one! bye Thanks for chatting. goodbye

If you fight in a war you should fight to win, and that means some "innocents" getting killed. So you believe there should be no rules in war? Pretty much.  I mean, there are considerations to be made.  Like, if we violate the Geneva Convention it all but assures there will be ramifications for our troops.  But war is life and death. So give me your perspective on Yemen.  How do you think that problem should be dealt with?  Keep fighting the Houtis, or concede and allow them to take over the country and government they've overthrown (with Iran's backing). To be honest, I would like them fight and only give aid to the citizens. So just let the old regime and the Houthi rebels fight, and whoever wins gets to control the country?  While the rest of the world stays out of it except for aid? Look at the US involvement in the middle east. Iraq is worst and Libya is now a hell hole.

Yeah, I'm not arguing with what you said (although I personally don't agree).  I'm just trying to understand.  Are you concerned that the Houthis are backed by Iran, and are being used by Iran to increase their influence in the region? We do not live over there, We can not say why they are fighting. We only get news reported to us. I do not think Iran can do any major damage to the US. I think it's pretty clear the Iranians are involved.  They're fighting proxy wars all over the place.  They're an existential threat to Israel, our top alley in the region.  Besides, when (not if) they get a nuke, plus ICMBs, they present a threat to a huge chunk of the world, far beyond the region, including possibly us through a suitcase bomb or dirty bomb. By your own logic, Israel if full of coach roaches too, (I do not agree) So why care what happens to them? Sure, but they're OUR cockroaches.  Also, I'm sorry, but Iran is truly bad.  I understand the the US does bad stuff, but it's not state-sponsored terrorism like Iran.  We're not the bad guys in the world.  I know that post-911 and post-Iraq we often like to think we're really the bad guys.  But no, Iran is bad.  Russia is bad.  China is bad.  North Korea is bad.  There are levels of bad, and these guys are the worst. I agree, but we are not messing with Russia or China if we really wanted to go after the bad guys. We should do more with them, I think.  Not a hot war, where the ramifications are too great though.  See, I'm realistic too.  Anyway, interesting chat.  Thanks.  bye You too, bye

How do you feel about these, basically, Russian suicide communities? I guess I think it's sad that kids feel so sad and alienated (or whatever) that they are drawn to them.  But I also think it's pitiful that people lose themselves in internet groups like this.  It's artificial. Artificial? How do you mean? I just think that the emotions we experience online are very different--much more intense--than what we experience in reality.  Ironically.  If we'd turn off our phones and the TV and went outside, we'd discover that there's a big difference between the virtual worlds on our screens, and the real world.  And the time we spend in the virtual ones doesn't seem to be good for our mental health, especially when we're already vulnerable.

It's true, a disturbing amount of humans put more effort into cultivating and maintaining a paltry digital simulacrum of themselves than they do their actual body/mind/relationships. I think in a lot of ways, for children growing up in our world, the digital world is much more real than the one that physically surrounds them everyday. I agree, and I think that's sad.  It's ironic that in mental health, mindfulness is the current push.  And I think that the way we engage with the internet is the antithesis of being mindful.  So you have this strange dichotomy where more people need, or think they need, mental health help, which will push them towards things like mindfulness, while those same people do the exact opposite thing while engaging in their virtual worlds. Mindfulness, in essence, is non-committal engagement of ones thoughts and feelings; acknowledging them as they are and letting them pass over you. The internet, on the other hand, is potentially a coliseum of unhinged emotional responses to both real world and subjective events and opinions. I think you're absolutely correct. People in our society are very quick to diagnose themselves, but rarely exert the effort to actually plumb the depths of their personal experience with a person who is qualified to make those diagnoses. I'd suggest that in this story, the parents are most capable of providing help, in all ways, but apparently the parents are a large part of the problem, what with the drinking and abuse and whatnot.

I think they are the most capable and most incapable in the same turn depending on the circumstances. I think more actual community involvement is key in these types of situations. Less time online and more time interacting with human beings toward a common goal. The statistics intrigued me.  First, the inordinately high depression and suicide rates for Russia.  But also the 5% number (teenage depression, I believe it was) for the rest of the West.  That number seems low to me, though I don't really know. If factor in western countries with higher quality of life (Noway, Sweden, Denmark, Netherlands) whose suicide rates are less then 1% i'm sure it skews the data. I'd also suggest that the FOCUS on the internet communities themselves is maybe misguided.  Seems like a whack-a-mole problem in terms of shutting them down.

It's much easier to make a half hearted effort to apply blame and deal with superficial corollaries of social problems than address them at the root. Absolutely.  A culture of victimhood.  But it does nothing to help the actual kids. No, meaningful action against this problem would require time, money, empathy and a sense of duty to ones fellow man that is very scarce in the world today. It's the equivalent of cutting hair and just expecting it not to grow back. I also wonder what the right balance is for issues pertaining to mental illness and health.  At what point does "help" and "sympathy" becoming enabling and rationalizing?  When does trying to eliminate stigma becoming encouraging people to self-diagnose and use mental health as a crutch, or excuse. Well, help and sympathy are two mutually exclusive concepts. A lot of the time people who are experiencing intense isolation just need someone to talk to. I think that people who are actually diagnosed rely too heavily on prescription medication (which are only supposed to be a temporary crutch) and prefer to ignore the human element in therapy which is often the most beneficial. I'd agree with that.  In all parts of medicine, prescribing a pill has become the easy, satisfying thing to do. I'm flabbergasted when I see reports quoting the number of people taking things like Ambien. Ambien, antibiotics, anti-depressants. It's a depressing and short sighted landscape to be sure. Thanks so much for chatting. I think you were probably the most insightful person so far. bye Yes, nice chatting with you.  Have a nice day.  bye

I also think our brains have a difficult time comprehending things that don't occur in our experienced time frames. Hey there.  I find it distressing anytime human technology is leading to the death of animals.  It seems so very frequent and common.  What did you think? Yes, we certainly have a habit of encroaching on animals' habitats and doing harm to them. Yes indeed we do.  It's really unfair to them but it's like an inevitable thing as society continues to grow. Yes, there will always be compromises to be made.  Do we trade more greenhouse gasses for more dead birds, etc.  We're something of an invasive species and will continue to do what we do.  I think the question is just how, precisely, and what we choose to compromise.

Yes I agree.  It seems particularly sad when it is an endangered species that is being compromised.  I did not see anything in the article about what they planned to do to fix the situation, did you? No, I didn't.  They were just talking about using this finding as further food-for-thought for wind farms.  I've also always wondered whether wind farms affect weather patterns.  You can't just take energy out of the air "for free."  That affects something.  I wonder if, like this bird situation, we truly understand the ramifications of these wind farms, and whether it's the right alternative energy to be pursuing so aggressively. Yeah I agree with what you are saying completely.  It seems like in trying to fix things, there are often unintended consequences that further harm other things. Yes, and we start down a path without being fully informed about what the ramifications are.  We did the same thing 100+ years ago with coal and oil!

Yeah totally!  And so many other things.  You would think we would have learned our lesson by now but nope. Indeed.  I do wonder if there are specific things they can do to protect the birds, though.  Someone must be thinking of something.  Like, scents that deter them, or colors or something.  I don't know much about birds but you'd think there'd be some way to scare them or deter them from those locations. Yeah that is a really good point.  You would think there would be something.  Surely scientists have vetted this out? I would think so, but maybe it isn't a high priority or something.  I'm guessing the companies with a vested interest in wind farms don't want the bird killing to be paid attention to.  And maybe animal rights groups don't have the resources or something.  Not sure but I personally never hear that much about wind farms, positive or negative.  Energy talk tends to center around oil and coal.

Yeah I don't hear much about it either.  I don't really seek out that info though but I do read the news every day and I never see anything about it.  I have heard about the bird issue just over the years in different settings.  It seems to be an ongoing issue for sure. I'd be interested to see how people felt if we just lay all the cards on the table.  Obviously we aren't this knowledgeable, but if we just said, "These are the pros and cons of wind, solar, oil, nuclear, etc. what do the people prefer?"  In other words, what do you sacrifice?  Dead birds, cost, nuclear fears, Carbon dioxide/global warming, etc.  I'd be interested to see how people chose because, again, you have to compromise somewhere. Yeah totally.  It's easy for people to sit there and throw out idealistic notions but when it really came down to the practicality of it all and the pros and cons were laid out including cost, what would people choose Right.  And I also feel like we, the people, don't get to have that much say.  This is a larger conversation than we have time for, but my energy costs have spiked dramatically in the last few years because the energy company is going towards wind, and it's expensive.  I'm not saying that isn't what I'd ultimately choose, but I don't even get a choice.  I have one utility company and have to accept their monopoly. That is a good point as far as not getting any input.  Our costs have gone up too and we only have one company to choose from. The other thing I'd be interested about is what rodent populations are like around these wind farms.  If you kill all the birds of prey, how does that affect these lands for farming or grazing.  You wonder if land owners, who've agreed to have these wind turbines erected on their lands, will regret it. Oh yes true, ike the other populations will get out of control.  It could set the entire ecosystem out of balance.  Such is the danger when we tamper with nature. Different countries/cultures/economies see the world very differently.  In the west, in our relative prosperity, we focus on certain things.  And in these high-population, low-wealth countries, they focus on much more basic goals.  Sort of like a Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs thing.  The point is, getting everyone to go along with some worldwide issue like reducing greenhouse gases, is extremely difficult if not impossible. Yeah I agree.  It's like we are on different pages. This is certainly a contentious issue. It is very much. I am afraid we're going to keep seeing it. However, I feel we are only getting half the story and we're only making national headlines about cops shooting people and not people shooting cops. Yes, I like to say that just because a story is true, doesn't make it representative of the country as a whole.  If the news decided to run stories about kidnappings, they could very easily have the country go into a panic over that.  We get just the slightest sliver of a glimpse of the country through the news, and it skews our perspective. I totally agree. We tend to see the media picking and choosing what they focus on. We don't even get a fair representation of happenings. Instead, we get a skewed view to press a political hot button and not giving a fair understanding of the incidents.

Right.  A narrative gets created and information either adds to it or gets disregarded.  For example, blacks are actually killed less often by police than whites based on encounter rates, but that piece of data has no place in politically-charged inflammatory subjects like this one.  Only emotions and strawmen do. I couldn't agree more. Just like more blacks kill one another than are shot by cops, but we make it out as if the only people killing black people are cops. I wish we would get a better representation of facts in the media to educate people. That was how media was supposed to work. These days it seems more like they simply want to grab headlines and push political agendas. Yeah, I think it's pretty sad.  The other thing I say to people is to use their own experiences to guide their beliefs more than stuff they see on screens.  How many hundreds of thousands of POSITIVE, PRODUCTIVE, LEGAL, and APPROPRIATE police encounters occur each day for every one that goes horribly wrong?  Again, a cop might shoot and murder an innocent civilian, but that's not our reality.  The event might be the truth.  But it's not representative of the true state of the nation and what the vast, vast, vast majority of people experience in their lives instead of on screens. I couldn't have said it better myself. We tend to take the extreme cases that make the headlines and make that the normal reality when it is far from the truth. I just recently saw a video of a black man with a knife. He was ordered to drop it and continued to advance on the cop. The man was shot several times, went down and then jumped back up. He attacked a second officer before he was finally taken down. That video didn't make headlines to show how often cops have little choice but to defend themselves.

Yeah, precisely.  I also ask myself in these issues, how much danger do we expect these cops to put themselves in?  How close to certain death do we expect them to come before they're allowed to defend themselves?  I'm sorry but it's not hard to get a cop not to abuse you: do what he says.  They don't have any more desire to get violent than you do. I've said the same thing many times myself. I've had interactions with cops and never had any violence or threat of violence. If an officer asks you to do something, do it! That's what I was taught growing up. Respect authority figures. Instead, today everyone thinks they don't have to listen to anyone. They don't respect authority. They want to live stream it and get reactions on social media. Yes, that's the question I want answered.  It's not, "Why are people getting shot by police?"  It's, "Why is there a generation of people, and apparently predominantly blacks, who don't think they have to respect the law and law enforcement?" I'm afraid it's what they are being taught by parents, social media and even music. They are told people are, "out to get them" and so they don't have to listen to anyone -- not just cops, but teachers and anyone in authority. It's a sad state of affairs I'm afraid.

Yes, I think that teachers and principals have largely abdicated their authority and influence.  Heck, even parents, who often seem more intent on being friends than authority figures to their children. Well we don't enforce any rules on children anymore. We don't punish them. We give them time outs, as if that will teach them anything. I got spanked a few times growing up and I learned how to behave. Yes, some children were abused, but the majority of parents used spanking properly and taught children how to behave. Now, kids threaten to call CPS on parents if they don't get their way. Yes, I think it's sad an ironic.  I often wonder how a generation of people who were spanked but couldn't possibly believe they were abused, could go on to think spanking is so wrong.  I have a theory but it'd take too long to discuss here.  Just a weird irony, in my opinion. It is. It's like everything in society now, though. We have gone to the extreme to avoid upsetting anyone or offending anyone. Doesn't anymore remember the old saying, "You can't please all of the people, all of the time!" Suddenly, everyone thinks they get to always have their way no matter what because otherwise, I'm offended!

Yeah, it's just crazy.  Even the people who believe that's how it should be can't help offending people.  There's always someone who's going to be offended.  We should be teaching people to be responsible and resilient, not to see themselves as victims. It's back to that everyone get's a trophy theory. We suddenly can't disappoint anyone. Life is full of disappointment. We can't always have our own way. We're supposed to live by the majority rules theory. However, even in politics we see people forget that. Instead, don't like the president, then refuse to accept him. It's crazy. I've voted for plenty of people that didn't win elections but still respected those that did. Absolutely.  And the ultimate irony is that by trying to make everyone's life struggle-free, we increase their struggles by making everyone less capable of dealing with them.  We know it's unhealthy and unproductive to treat kids like this, make them soft and feeble.  It's not just silly, it's actually detrimental to the people we're trying to protect. Exactly! Instead of letting them learn when they're young and the disappointments are more minor that they can survive not always getting what they want. We let them grow up thinking everything should go their way. Then suddenly, they don't get into the college they want or get the job they want and they can't deal with it. Yeah, it's a bizarre tack we've taken and I wonder when it or if we'll change course.  Anyway, it was great talking with you.  I really enjoyed it.  Hope you have a great day.  bye Was great chatting with you as well. Enjoy your day. goodbye

Yeah, and that's the problem. We're just content with what we're given. Police departments and Fire departments are forms of socialism but people don't complain about them. Yeah, our values are just out of whack. But, again, it is who we are. We want to point a finger at some 'other', some boogeyman, because it's easier and safer than point a finger at a crooked system, because that seems like too big of a problem to solve. The government has long stopped working in the interest of the common man.

True, but it's not just the government, it's everything, all of it. The whole structure and processes of society. It's a massive problem that will only be solved if we reach some crisis that necessitates huge change. Climate change or an asteroid. Yes, something at that level. People won't change unless their comfort is threatened. It doesn't have to be existential, but big enough to rattle everyone. Do you think police should be enforcing laws dealing with what an adult does with their own body?

Well, I think there are way too many laws governing personal behavior. Most things that do not directly harm others should be legal. Abortion. Suicide. Gambling. Prostitution. Some drugs. Legalize, regulate and tax. The problem isn't the act themselves, it's the criminality, which breeds abuse and exploitation, because where can you turn if you know that what you're doing could get you locked up? I can see how see how some women can be forced into prostitution. I believe all drugs should be legal. I would hate for one of my children to overdose, but I would also hate for one of my children to die from a heart attack from eating Big Macs all day which is not illegal. Yes, that's right. Our society shouldn't punish people for making what others would deem to be a mistake. It should be more forgiving and permissive. Drug addition should not be a criminal matter - it should be viewed as a public health matter. Do you think we should make police less militarized?

Probably, but I also think that there should be way more police. And, yeah, the role of police should shift away from 'catching bad guys' to supporting communities. As a man this makes me sick to see other men behave this way. It's definitely an issue that's existed forever and I wonder whether it can truly change. Your right, I do not think it will change either. I'm afraid that it's also become such a contentious issue that it's hard to even trust allegations anymore when they're in the political sphere.  Which is very sad for people who do experience actual harassment.

It is hard but when you hear somebody say grab them by the P, it is not hard to see that person actually doing that. Sure, although the person you're referring to also makes a lot of boasts and claims that are not true, so who's to say that wasn't just him bragging.  I'm just saying that every time there's a false allegation, and there are, it undermines the credibility of every single woman who legitimately experiences it. I agree that some woman make false allegations, but I do not think it is the majority. I agree, I think most allegations have some truth.  But I also think we've gotten hysterical about this stuff, so when someone says, "I was sexually harassed," or even "assaulted," I don't know what that means.  I think that's unfortunate too.

It is the climate we live in today. Some of the claims you say, wait a minute that does not sound right, but we should still listen. The other thing about these issues is that we just seem to cycle through them and then lose interest and go onto something else.  Sexual harassment, blacks getting shot by cops, mass shooting, something Trump has done, North Korea or Russia or China, and then back to someone being sexually harassed.  It's just weird how quickly these issues come and go and then come back again, seemingly with no progress, just more ire. Yeah all of these issues need to be addressed in the proper manner. The world is so fast paced that most people do not have time to worry about issues that do not effect them. I think we were all a lot happier when we were less "informed."  Connection and information are a double-edged sword, if nothing else.

We would be happier, but some people would be suffering in the dark. Sure.  But are they being helped now?  I guess that's the question. Yes, because more men are thinking about their behavior. That's probably true.  Do you think there are any downsides? Yes, some women are over reacting and some are flat out lying. What do you think? I think it's a mixed bag.  I think the goal of having women not sexually harassed and assaulted is good and I agree some people are probably thinking about their behavior or even changing it now.  But I think the general relationship between men and women is strained and growing contentious.  I'm not sure how to address some of these issues without that happening, unfortunately.  But I think that, at times, there is a definite "men versus women" mentality growing in the country and world, and, at least in the short term, it's harmful in ways.  Is the end result worth it?  Maybe. But it's still an issue, I think.

I found this article obnoxious.  What were your thoughts on it? Obnoxious in what sense? It attempted to blame an increase in hate crimes (which it later retracted, saying they were likely at the same level as they were in 2015) on Trump. Yeah, but the media's pretty good at that, aren't they?  I don't think Trump creates anger and hatred.  He might embolden it.  Maybe.  But it already exists and is a function of our society, not one man.

Those are my exact sentiments.  It is a mindset that has entered society and is probably exacerbated by social media and the rapid exchange of information, ideas, hatred, and anger that is prevalent in society today.  To blame it on Trump, one person, is just absurd. I also sympathize fully with people who are furious after terrorist attacks.  I personally wouldn't go harass or assault an innocent person because of it, but I understand the feelings behind it, even if I don't condone the behavior. Yes, and there have been a large number of terrorist incidents that were perpetrated by Muslims.  So to me, that would explain why people are targeting Muslims in retaliation.  Which is not right at all, but it is the explanation for why that is happening. I guess I also feel that the notion of everyone living together peacefully and harmoniously is misguided.  There will always be winners and losers, always be some sort of "us versus them."  You see it in gender issues, race issues, political issues.  I think certain majority elements in our society are waking up to this and pushing back.  And I don't blame them.

You make a good point.  That is probably an idealistic notion that is not grounded in reality.  I do wish people would learn to live and let live a little bit more.  Just mind their own business and enjoy their lives. Yes, I don't want to present too cynical and callous a view.  People can form stable societies.  But our current one likes to highlight differences and perceived inequalities, and that feeds a very antagonistic culture.  I think we know too much about each other, see too much that other people have that we don't, and it creates unrealistic expectations about how the world can possibly work.  We don't all get to have what we want.  Few, or none, do Yes and social media probably feeds into that.  Not to keep blaming social media for all our problems because I certainly don't think that's the case, but I Do think it heightens the issue you are describing.  People see differences and inequalities and just have much more information than they did in the past. Yeah, don't feel bad about ripping on social media.  I think it's a real problem.  Or, as you say, it heightens all these problems.  I think it's a real problem and will be interested to see how things unfold going forward, whether people start turning away from it or they double down and more of our lives gets filtered through our screens.  The problem is it's addictive for people, among other things, and I think that makes it harder for people to decide not to use it, even when they know it makes them unhappy.

Yeah it definitely becomes compulsive for people, like an integrated and critical part of their lives almost.  Something did not really happen unless it's documented on social media.  Kinda crazy to me, but whatever.  Either way, I do think it is intensifying a lot of these problems and it will definitely be interesting to see what happens over the next century. Yeah, I thought about that once.  Think about how much our minds now associated "importance" with seeing it on a screen.  We've been conditioned to think that way.  And I think it works the other way, too.  When we see something, we make it important by recording it.  A strange phenomenon, that something isn't important until it's digitized. It is a very strange phenomenon.  And it has happened so fast.  It's crazy to think when I was a kid the only phones we had were in the house, and the computer was basically just a very simple word processor.  My kids can't even fathom it.  We used a phone book to look up a phone number. Yeah, I was the same.  I don't even have a cell phone myself.  I'm annoyed that so few people are now in the phone book.  Some places apparently don't even have phone books anymore. Yeah I don't even know where I would get a phone book.  They don't distribute them where I live.  I have a cell phone but it stays off on a shelf unless I leave the house.  It is for emergency use when I am out. Yeah, I don't ever judge people for having a cell phone.  I just joke that "I'm not that important," which has more meaning than I let on, but I mostly mean as a joke. LOL apparently I am not either.  But I am perfectly fine with that.  This is how I choose to live my life.  Well it has been a pleasure speaking with you, thank you for sharing your insights with me.  I hope you enjoy the rest of your day, goodbye For sure, great chatting with you.  I enjoyed it and appreciate your perspective.  Have a great day.  bye

Reading about that situation with the poachers was pretty upsetting. To think that the changes being made to ensure poaching ends and they are being stopped by local governments is just upsetting. Yes, although I'm not sure it was local governments, just local villagers.  Still, that must have been a horribly frightening experience. Yeah that could be possible, and so terrifying to just be doing your job and being attacked like that. I wonder if this is the right way to stop poaching, or if there was a better way than having people just have to grab poachers in towns like that. Yes, I'm not sure.  The whole article was a little sparse on details, which I would have appreciated.  It didn't explicitly say what the villagers were angry about, although one could guess.  And I also wondered who called for the helicopter.  Seems unlikely the rangers would have survived that scenario, but who knows.

Yeah it definetely felt like the article just wanted you to just to the conclusions on your own. I'm guessing the poachers were members of the community and that caused the mob. I wonder how the poahcer even got away from them in the first place. Yes, the fact that he escaped seemed incompetent, unfortunately.  But of course that's a large part of the story.  There aren't enough resources or competence to properly deal with the issue.  And there's probably corruption, too. Yeah for sure as easy as it seems there is so much ground for them to cover and animals to protect. If only they had more resources or there was a way to stop black market trade so poachers are not incentivized to hunt these animals. Yes, I think that's one of the tacks governments are taking is to focus on the demand.  Not sure how well it's worked but they're definitely putting pressure on things like ivory demand, maybe similar to same way that there's sort of a backlash against blood diamonds.  I was curious what animals were being poached in this story.  I don't believe it said, did it?

No i don't think there was a mention of it. They only mentioned the country and the continent so the first thing my mind jumped to was to african elephants which i think are still endangered. I definitely think that there is progress being made on poaching and hope stories like this are not commen. Yes, I think it's particularly disheartening when the story is of the authorities losing the battle.  I guess I feel like if nothing is currently being done to stop it, then there's the distinct possibility that change can and will happen.  But if they're already trying and failing, then it feels less likely to me that things can improve. Yeah for sure, it seems like we never really hear articles that are good news or updates on constant issues. Or maybe that is that people know that those articles would not cause as much noise so there is less interest in talking about them. Yes, I certainly think that's part of it.  I'm curious what will happen to the people in the village?  The article is concerned about the cowardly police officers, and I get that.  But will there be any charges brought to the villagers for nearly killing the rangers?  I'd like to know that.

I don't think there is any good way to deal with the villagers, if it was a mob of people that attacked them then what do you do arrest them all? I think at best the rangers just now no they must be careful with that village. Yes, that's a good point.  Unfortunately, I think it only serves to embolden and legitimize their actions.  If there are no repercussions for waging "war" on anti-poaching, then how can the anti-poaching side ever have any real authority and success? Definetely it sends the message that if you want to poach then just make sure that the nearest village is benefiting from it and you wont need to worry. Maybe the government sends people to the villages to work as police or peacekeepers of some sort but that could just make tensions worse. Yeah, if nothing else I'd certainly be nervous to be the guy sent there, seeing how they treated these rangers.  I feel like you'd probably have to convince people associated with poaching that there's an economically viable alternative to their poaching.  The problem is that I'm not sure what that is in Mozambique. Yeah me either, it seems like all these people see is the money lost from not poaching. It feels bad but maybe there should be incentives for villages if the population of poached animals gets above a certain point? Yes, that's certainly an idea.  I think it's just human nature.  It's Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs.  We can entertain ideas of democracy and harmony and enlightenment and whatever, so long as we're fed and clothed and housed.  But if our basic needs aren't being met, we're going to scrap and claw for what sustains us, broader society and the world be damned. Definetely, and people can only really see things for their immediate self. It is hard to think of the overall elephant population when you are now going hungry because you cannot hunt them. Oh well, even though it was about a harsh topic it was nice talking to you. goodbye Yes, I appreciated your perspective.  It made me think.  Thanks for taking the time to chat.  Have a nice day.  bye
